title: Brexit ‘has been a waste of time and energy’, says Jean-Claude Juncker
text:
Jean-Claude Juncker and Donald Tusk have said the next moves by the EU depend on this week’s events in Westminster (Picture: EPA)

EU officials have criticised politicians in Westminster, saying the repeated delays to Brexit have been a ‘waste of time and energy.’

As MPs prepare to challenge Boris Johnson’s drive to push the new divorce bill through the House of Commons, patience on the mainland appears to be wearing thin.

European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker insisted the EU had done ‘all in our power’ to ensure an orderly Brexit.

He said the bloc would await decisions by Westminster but noted the EU had done a lot of work in the three years since the referendum.

Speaking in Strasbourg, he said: ‘It has pained me to spend so much time of this mandate dealing with Brexit.

‘It has been a waste of time and a waste of energy.

‘The Commission has worked tirelessly to negotiate an agreement with the UK.’

Expressing regret that Britain plans to leave, Juncker added: ‘At least we can look ourselves in the eyes and say that we have done all in our power to make sure that this departure is orderly.

‘We need now to watch events in Westminster very closely.

‘It’s not possible, not imaginable that this parliament will ratify the agreement before Westminster will have ratified the agreement.’

Boris Johnson is trying to sell his new 110-page deal to colleagues in Westminster (Picture: AP)

His words were echoed by European Council President Donald Tusk who said that the EU’s next steps were dependent on Westminster.

Today Mr Johnson wants MPs to back his Brexit deal in a final bid to leave the EU in nine days’ time.

MPs will vote on the Withdrawal Bill and if they back it, they will be asked to approve a three-day timetable to consider legislation.

The decision to allow only three days has sparked anger from the opposition benches because the new bill is 110 pages long with 124 pages of explanatory notes.

Labour are likely to attach amendments to the timetable including pushing for a vote on remaining in the customs union and a second referendum.

If they happen, Mr Johnson could pull his bill – putting the ball in the court of the EU about whether they grant an extension or we crash out with no deal on October 31.

Mr Tusk said EU leaders would ‘decide in the coming days’ whether to grant Britain another extension.

He added it ‘will very much depend on what the British parliament does or doesn’t decide.

‘We should be ready for every scenario but one thing must be clear.

‘As I said to Prime Minister Johnson, a no-deal Brexit will never be our decision.’
